revised_title: Procedural Theories of Linguistic Performance: A Reevaluation of Competence and Performance Distinction
tldr: The author argues that the distinction between competence and performance in linguistic theory is valuable but the separation of questions of grammaticality from questions of naturalness or intelligibility has outlived its usefulness. A generative grammar should be accompanied by a specification of processes by which ideas can be encoded in words and decoded by the hearer. The author provides examples of effective procedures implemented as computer programs for specific linguistic tasks, such as numeral systems in natural languages.
